qas.question: Who argued that emotions arise from cognitive intentionality?
Along with evaluations and thoughts, what cognitive activity did theorists believe to be required for emotion?
In Lazarus' view, what could the cognitive activity be if it was not conscious?
Who argued that emotions don't come from cognitive intentionality?
Along with evaluations and thoughts, what cognitive activity did theorists not believe to be required for emotion?
In Lazarus' view, what couldn't the cognitive activity be if it was not conscious?

context: With the two-factor theory now incorporating cognition, several theories began to argue that cognitive activity in the form of <a1_0><b4_0>judgments<b4_0/><a1_0/>, evaluations, or thoughts were entirely necessary for an emotion to occur. One of the main proponents of this view was <a0_0><b3_0>Richard Lazarus<b3_0/><a0_0/> who argued that emotions must have some cognitive intentionality. The cognitive activity involved in the interpretation of an emotional context may be conscious or <a2_0><b5_0>unconscious<b5_0/><a2_0/> and may or may not take the form of conceptual processing.
